|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/ban-sanatan-sanstha-maharashtra-to-centre/845643/ |accessdate=15 March 2012 |newspaper=The Indian Express |date=13 September 2011 }}</ref> A central government investigation of the group was ongoing. On 2 December 2015, the [[Minister of Home Affairs (India)|Minister of Home Affairs]] stated in the upper house ([[Rajya Sabha]]) that there was no proposal to ban Sanatan Sanstha.<ref name="IND-GOV"/>
The organization's public image was sullied by allegations of involvement in unlawful activities. Hence it started a series of public meetings in different cities in Maharashtra to dispel what it called "misunderstandings".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/sanatan-sanstha-to-go-among-people-to-allay-misunderstanding/16629177 |title=Sanatan Sanstha to go among people to allay 'misunderstanding' - News |website=Mid-day.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
====Convictions==== On 30 August 2011, Ramesh Gadkari and Vikram Bhave were convicted in sessions court of the Thane blasts and sentenced to ten years rigorous imprisonment.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/other-states/article2412137.ece |title=Theatre blast convicts get 10 years in jail |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=31 August 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Two get 10 years in jail for Thane blasts |publisher=[[Hindustan Times]] |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Two-get-10-years-in-jail-for-Thane-blasts/Article1-739869.aspx }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-31/mumbai/29949031_1_imprisonment-vishnu-bhave-auditorium-rangayatan |title=10-yr jail term for 2 Thane blast convicts |publisher=[[Times of India]] |author=Rebecca Samervel |date=31 August 2011 }}</ref> Judgment of trail court was further challenged in the Bombay (Mumbai) High Court and on 2 May 2013 that court ordered the release of the accused on bail while awaiting hearing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.indlawnews.com/NewsDisplay.aspx?b5c93ed1-e5f7-471a-97a2-77faa8ad8ef0 |title=Bombay HC grants bail to accused in Thane theatre blast case |work= www.indlawnews.com|date=2 May 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tehelka.com/right-wing-member-gets-bail-in-2008-thane-blasts-case/ |title=Right wing member gets bail in 2008 Thane blasts case |work=www.tehelka.com |date=8 May 2013 }}</ref>
===Goa blast=== Six members of the Sanstha arrested in the Goa blast case under UAPA were acquitted by the special [[National Investigation Agency]] (NIA) court for want of evidence, while UAPA remains in force against three Sanstha members who are absconding.<ref name=realquestions /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/377725/court-acquits-sanatan-sanstha-members.html |title=Court acquits Sanatan Sanstha members in 2009 Goa blast|newspaper= ''[[Deccan Herald]]''|date =1 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/2009-goa-blast-court-acquits-sanatan-sanstha-members/article5524938.ece |title=2009 Goa blast: court acquits Sanatan Sanstha members |newspaper= [[The Hindu]] |date =1 Jan 2014}}</ref> Rudra Patil and Sandeep Arolkar or Sarang Akolkar alias Kulkarni were declared absconders by the NIA, with a [[red corner notice]] issued against Patil.<ref name=villagersdemandbanET />
===Govind Pansare murder=== A member of the Sanatan Sanstha was arrested for the murder of [[Govind Pansare]].<ref name=realquestions /> The Special Investigation Team investigating the murder, arrested Sanstha member Sameer Gaikwad and was on the lookout for another member Rudra Patil, who is absconding since the 2009 Goa blast.<ref name=Waghdemandsban /> The prosecution stated in court that Sameer Gaikwad was in different city (Thane) around the time of the murder of [[Govind Pansare]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/mumbai/pansare-killing-gaikwad-was-in-thane-around-time-of-murder-phone-records-suggest-complicity-prosecution/ |title=Pansare killing- Gaikwad was in Thane around time of murder, phone records suggest complicity: Prosecution |newspaper=[[The Indian Express]] |date=24 September 2015}}</ref> [[Minister of Home Affairs (India)|Minister of Home Affairs]] Ranjit Patil claimed that the arrest of Sameer Gaikwad was based only on suspicion, and that the only proof is a cellphone conversation about killing Pansare.<ref name="asianage.com"/> Eventually, it was revealed that the evidence against Gaikwad is strong, as he was present at the scene of the crime, and he had discussed the murder with other Sanatan Sanstha members.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/pune/pansare-murder-chargesheet-arrested-sanatan-member-was-on-crime-spot-cops/ |title=Pansare murder Chargesheet: ‘Teen saw Sanatan member on crime spot’ |newspaper=[[The Indian Express]] |date=2015-12-15 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> Sanatan Sanstha was also planning to create a 15,000-strong armed force.<ref>{{cite news |author=Vijay Kumar Yadav |url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/sanatan-sanstha-wanted-to-raise-army-of-15000-to-target-anti-hindus/17332199 |title=Sanatan Sanstha wanted to raise army of 15,000 to target 'anti-Hindus' |website=Mid-day.com |date=14 June 2016 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
===Narendra Dabholkar murder=== Indian investigative agencies believe that the Sanatan Sanstha is implicated in the murder of [[Narendra Dabholkar]].<ref name=investigatingagencies>{{cite news |author=Rana Ayyub |url=http://www.dailyo.in/politics/sanatan-sanstha-narendra-dabholkar-govind-pansare-anti-superstition-hindutva-maharashtra/story/1/2492.html |title=Why investigating agencies believe Sanatan Sanstha is behind Dabholkar and Pansare's murder |website=Dailyo.in |date=3 October 2015 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
In June 2016, Virendrasinh Tawade,a member of Hindu Janjagruti Samiti (HJS), an offshoot of Sanatan Sanstha, was arrested in connection with the murder.<ref>{{cite news |agency=PTI |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/crime/110616/dabholkar-murder-case-cbi-makes-first-arrest-sanatan-sanstha-member-held.html |title=Three years after Dabholkar's murder, CBI arrests Sanatan Sanstha member |website=Deccanchronicle.com |date=11 June 2016 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goanconnection.com/goa-news/all-eyes-on-sanatan-sanstha-after-ent-specialist-s-arrest |title=All eyes on Sanatan Sanstha after ENT specialist’s arrest |publisher=Goan Connection |date=2016-06-11 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> An official of the CBI revealed that emails exchanged between Tawade and his underground colleague Sarang Akolkar, from 2008 to 2013, discuss procurement of weapons and establishment of a weapon-manufacturing unit.<ref>{{cite web |author= |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/Sanatan-Sanstha-men-talked-arms-in-emails-CBI/articleshow/52720983.cms |title=Sanatan Sanstha men talked arms in emails: CBI - Times of India |website=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2016-06-13 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
===Kalburgi murder=== MLA [[Vishnu Wagh]] has said that there is evidence of the Sanstha's involvement in the murder of Kannada scholar [[M. M. Kalburgi]].<ref name=Waghdemandsban /> On 16 October 2015, the Karnataka CID team said that they didn't see involvement of Sanatan's activist Sameer Gaikwad in the murder of Kalburgi and so they were not going to seek his custody for any further investigation.<ref name="newindianexpress.com"/>
===Gauri Lankesh murder=== Sanatan members were suspected of involvement in the murder of [[Gauri Lankesh]] in 2017.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=India Times |title=Gauri Lankesh murder: SIT probing Sanatan Sanstha angle |author=Krishna Kumar |date=15 September 2017 |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/gauri-lankesh-murder-sit-probing-sanatan-sanstha-angle/articleshow/60520120.cms }}</ref> They are being investigated and have been questioned by the Special Investigation Team probing the murder.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.asianage.com/india/all-india/170917/gauri-lankesh-murder-case-sanathan-sanstha-members-grilled.html |title=Gauri Lankesh murder: Sanathan Sanstha members grilled |work=The Asian Age |author=M. G. Chetan |date=17 September 2017 }}</ref> Forensic analysis has shown that the same pistol was used to kill Kalburgi,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://thewire.in/177301/forensic-analysis-finds-gun-used-kill-gauri-lankesh-m-m-kalburgi/ |work=The Wire |title=Forensic analysis finds same gun used to kill Gauri Lankesh and M.M. Kalburgi |date=14 September 2017 }}</ref> and is also possibly the same gun that was used to kill Narendra Dabholkar and Govind Pansare.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gun used to kill Gauri Lankesh is the same one that killed M M Kalburgi: forensics |work=Indian Express |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/gun-used-to-kill-gauri-lankesh-is-the-same-one-that-killed-m-m-kalburgi-forensics-4842625/ |author=T.A. Johnson |date=14 September 2017 }}</ref> Sanatan was implicated in all these murders. However, its representative denied having a hand in the murder of Gauri Lankesh.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sanatan denies hand in Gauri Lankesh murder |author=Prakash Kamat |date=16 September 2017 |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/sanatan-denies-hand-in-gauri-lankesh-murder/article19694574.ece }}</ref> An article in The Indian Express mentions that "at least three forensics laboratories — Chandigarh, Hyderabad and Gujarat — are equipped to study signatures through an integrated bullet identification system". The article also says that the Karnataka police are investigating if the Gauri Lankesh murder has any connection to three previous murders attributed to the Sanstha.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/explained/gauri-lankesh-killing-4-murders-2-suspected-firearms-and-a-forensic-effort-to-join-the-dots-4853410/|title=Gauri Lankesh killing: 4 murders, 2 suspected firearms and a forensic effort to join the dots|date=21 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
===Hypnosis=== Public interest litigations were filed in the Bombay High Court seeking a ban on the organisation, stating that it uses [[Ericksonian hypnosis]] to lure people into joining it and to carry out acts of violence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report_pil-seeks-ban-on-sanatan-sanstha_1626415 |title=PIL seeks ban on Sanatan Sanstha |location=Mumbai |publisher=Dnaindia.com |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/move-to-ban-sanatan-sanstha-pending-with-centre-ats/962691 |title=Move to ban Sanatan Sanstha pending with Centre: ATS |publisher=Indian Express |date= |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref> Such claims are rejected by Hamid Dabholkar, son of slain rationalist Narendra Dabholkar, saying that hypnotism could not provoke a person to cause violence and instead pointing at radicalization as the means of influence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/pune/sanatan-sanstha-in-crosshairs-dabholkar-aides-want-no-misfire/ |title=Sanatan Sanstha in crosshairs, Dabholkar aides want no misfire |newspaper=[[The Indian Express]] |date=4 October 2015 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
=== Explosives haul ===
In August 2018, Maharashtra [[Anti-Terrorism Squad (India)|Anti Terror Squad]] (ATS) had recovered 20 crude bombs, two gelatin sticks, 4 electronic and 22 non-electronic detonators, 150 grams explosive powder, two bottles labelled 'poison', batteries, soldering equipment, and a bomb circuit drawing from the house of Sanathan Sanstha worker Vaibhav Raut in [[Nala Sopara|Nallasopara]]<ref name="explosives_sanatan_worker">{{cite news |last1=Tare |first1=Kiran |title=ATS recovers explosives from Sanatan Sanstha worker Vaibhav Raut's residence |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/india/story/ats-recovers-explosives-from-sanatan-sanstha-worker-vaibhav-raut-s-residence-1310612-2018-08-10 |accessdate=19 August 2018 |publisher=[[India Today]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.firstpost.com/india/maharashtra-ats-arrests-three-people-with-explosives-one-affiliated-to-hindu-right-wing-outfit-sanatan-sanstha-4942391.html|title=Maharashtra ATS arrests 3, including Sanatan Sanstha associate, recovers crude bombs, gelatin sticks, explosive powder - Firstpost|website=www.firstpost.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Nair |first1=Sandhya |title=ATS raids home of Sanatan Sanstha member in Nalasopara |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/ats-raids-home-of-sanatan-sanstha-member-in-nalasopara/articleshow/65349875.cms |accessdate=19 August 2018 |publisher=[[Times of India|TOI]]}}</ref> Explosives and firearms were seized from [[Nala Sopara|Nallasopara]], [[Pune]] and [[Solapur]], and three other men, Sharad Kalaskar, Sudhanwa Gondhalekar and Shrikant Pangarkar were also arrested.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/explosives-case-sanatan-chief-may-be-questioned-police-118082101284_1.html|title=Explosives case: Sanatan chief may be questioned: Police|first=Press Trust of|last=India|date=21 August 2018|publisher=|via=Business Standard}}</ref>
=== Radicalisation ===
An Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS) officer said after members of the right-wing outfit were arrested in connection Dabholkar’s murder "Members of Sanatan Sanstha are ‘hard nuts to crack’, who communicate in code languages and have networks in at least four prominent cities of Maharashtra. They also have an 84-page rule book that asks them to 'chant Lord's name' before shooting a target". “They don’t speak unless confronted with evidence. They are indoctrinated, tutored, and given elaborate directions. It is not easy to extract information from them,” an officer involved in the probe told CNN-News18 on condition of anonymity.<ref >{{cite web|url=https://in.news.yahoo.com/apos-lord-weapon-time-apos-043134342.html |title='Lord Will Provide Weapon at Right Time': Straight Out of Sanatan Sanstha's Terror 'Handbook' |publisher=Yahoo News |website=Yahoo.com |date= 22 August 2018 |accessdate=2018-08-22}}</ref>
==Drug haul== In September 2016, the Maharashtra police’s Special Investigation Team (SIT), which is probing the February 2015 murder of communist leader Govind Pansare, seized 20 boxes of restricted drugs — including sleeping pills and suppressants — from the premises Sanatan Sanstha’s ashram in Panvel. An SIT official stated that "It is suspected that the drugs were being used to control the mind of followers at the ashram".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianage.com/mumbai/drugs-found-sanatan-ashram-409 |title=‘Drugs’ found at Sanatan ashram |publisher=Asianage.com |date=2016-09-10 |accessdate=2017-09-20}}</ref>
==Ban for Murder and Terrorism ==
===BJP=== * In September 2015, Goa [[BJP]] MLA, [[Vishnu Wagh]] demanded that Sanatan Sanstha be banned, stating that there was evidence of the involvement of Sanatan Sanstha in the Pansare and Karburgi murders, and comparing Sanatan Sanstha to SIMI.<ref name=Waghdemandsban>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/ban-sanatan-sanstha-demands-goa-bjp-lawmaker-vishnu-wagh-1220555 |title=Ban Sanatan Sanstha, Demands Goa BJP Lawmaker Vishnu Wagh |website=Ndtv.com |date=2015-09-22 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Like-SIMI-ban-Sanatan-Sanstha-for-creating-terror-says-Goa-BJP-MLA/articleshow/49065729.cms |title=Like SIMI, ban Sanatan Sanstha for 'creating terror', says Goa BJP MLA - Times of India |website=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date= |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> However, next day Chief Minister of [[Goa]], [[Laxmikant Parsekar]] ruled out banning Sanatan Sanstha.<ref name="GOACM"/> * [[Maharashtra]] Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis has stated that he would not hesitate to ban Sanatan Sanstha if any evidence found against the organisation.<ref name="MHCM">{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/if-proof-will-act-on-sanstha-devendra-fadnavis/ |title=If proof found against Sanatan Sanstha, will act on it: Devendra Fadnavis |newspaper=[[The Indian Express]] |date=2015-10-05 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
===AAP=== * Aam Aadmi Party have demanded a ban on the Sanatan Sanstha for the alleged murders they have been involved in.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestatesman.com/mobi/news/india/sanatan-sanstha-behind-free-thinkers-murders-should-be-banned-aap/146842.html |title=Sanatan Sanstha behind free-thinkers'' murders, should be banned: AAP |website=Thestatesman.com |date=2016-06-06 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
===NCP=== * In Maharashtra, [[Nationalist Congress Party|NCP]], together with the [[Indian National Congress|Congress]] demanded that Sanatan Sanstha be banned.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.oneindia.com/india/pansare-case-cong-ncp-demand-ban-on-sanatan-sanstha-1876639.html |title=Pansare case: Cong, NCP demand ban on Sanatan Sanstha |publisher=Oneindia |date=2015-09-22 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/mumbai/ncp-wants-ban-on-sanatan-sanstha/story-MHesyT4Pg4uioEADrvmNBP.html |title=Rationalist murder cases: NCP wants ban on Sanatan Sanstha | mumbai |publisher=Hindustan Times |date= |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> Nawab Malik of the NCP said that Sanatan Sanstha is a terrorist organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/video-gallery/general/sanatan-sanstha-is-a-terrorist-organization-should-be-immediately-banned-ncp-26278.htm |title=Sanatan Sanstha is a terrorist organization, should be immediately banned: NCP, Video Gallery |publisher=Business Standard |date= |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
===Congress=== * Former Maharashtra Chief Minister Prithviraj Chavan termed Sanatan Sanstha a dangerous organisation, and demanded that it be banned, and it's kingpin booked and punished. He referred to Sanatan Sanstha as 'terrorist elements that pose a threat to the country'.<ref name="MHCM" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/sanatan-sanstha-is-a-dangerous-organisation-says-former-maharashtra-cm-prithviraj-chavan-2829280.html |title=Sanatan Sanstha is a 'dangerous' organisation, says former Maharashtra CM Prithviraj Chavan |publisher=Firstpost |date= |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
===CPI and CPI(M)=== * The [[Communist Party of India|CPI]] and the [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)|CPI(M)]] have called for the Sanatan Sanstha to be banned, pointing out that the murders of Pansare, Dabholkar, Kalburgi and Gowri Lankesh are interconnected and followed the same method.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/gauri-lankesh-murder-left-sees-pattern-in-murders-calls-for-sansthas-ban-4832117/ |title=Gauri Lankesh murder: Left sees pattern in murders, calls for Sanstha’s ban |publisher=The Indian Express |date=2017-09-07 |accessdate=2017-09-20}}</ref>
===Government of Maharashtra=== * In April 2011, Prithviraj Chavan government send formal request to Central government for banning Sanatan Sanstha. However, due to lack of supporting evidences, Central government did not ban Sanatan Sanstha.<ref name="MHCM" /> * The BJP-Shiv Sena government in 2017 said that a proposal had been sent to the central government seeking a ban on Sanatan Sanstha.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/maharashtra-seeks-ban-on-right-wing-sanatan-sanstha-sends-proposal-to-centre/story-Gp1BCOlG8RsrhlSsZ0zJUJ.html |title=Maharashtra seeks ban on right wing Sanatan Sanstha, sends proposal to Centre | india-news |publisher=Hindustan Times |date= |accessdate=2017-09-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/minister-proposal-to-ban-sanatan-sanstha-pending-with-centre/article17856741.ece |title=Minister: proposal to ban Sanatan Sanstha pending with Centre |publisher=The Hindu |date=2017-04-07 |accessdate=2017-09-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/in-proposal-to-centre-maharashtra-govt-had-recommended-ban-on-sanatan-sanstha-minister-to-house-4602821/ |title=In proposal to Centre, Maharashtra govt had recommended ban on Sanatan Sanstha: Minister to House |publisher=The Indian Express |date=2017-04-07 |accessdate=2017-09-20}}</ref> * In August 2018, the Government of Maharashtra said that it would send a fresh request to the Central Government to ban Sanatan Sanstha.<ref>https://www.tribuneindia.com/news/nation/maharashtra-govt-pushes-for-ban-on-sanatan-sanstha/640517.html</ref>
===Samajwadi Party=== The [[Samajwadi Party]] demanded that Sanatan Sanstha be banned and asked the government to heighten security.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestatesman.com/india/sp-congress-reiterate-demand-to-ban-sanatan-sanstha-1502676048.html|title=SP, Congress reiterate demand to ban Sanatan Sanstha|date=21 August 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
===Others=== * The [[Sambhaji Brigade]] has called for Sanatan Sanstha to be banned for conspiracy and murder.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afternoondc.in/city-news/sambhaji-brigade-accuses-sanatan-sanstha-of-conspiracy-murder/article_170980 |title=Sambhaji Brigade accuses Sanatan Sanstha of conspiracy, murder |publisher=Afternoondc.in |date=2016-06-30 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> * This demand of the people for a ban also reflected online and on social media, with a petition on [[Change.org]] and a page on Facebook.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/Ban.Sanatan.Sanstha |title=Ban Sanatan Sanstha |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> * The daughter of Govind Pansare also called for the organisation to be banned.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/Ban-Sanatan-Sanstha-Govind-Pansares-Daughter/2015/09/23/article3043644.ece |title=Ban Sanatan Sanstha: Govind Pansare's Daughter |publisher=The New Indian Express |date= |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> * The government has been severely criticised for failing to ban Sanatan Sanstha; notably, the similarities with banned organisation [[Students Islamic Movement of India]] have been pointed out.<ref>{{cite web|author=Shoaib Daniyal |url=http://scroll.in/article/810325/the-daily-fix-as-terror-charges-against-sanatan-sanstha-grow-why-isnt-the-government-banning-it |title=The Daily Fix: As terror charges against Sanatan Sanstha grow, why isn’t the government banning it? |publisher=Scroll.in |date=2016-06-21 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Aakash Joshi |url=http://www.thequint.com/opinion/2016/06/20/sanatan-sanstha-vs-simi-what-is-the-litmus-test-for-a-ban-dabholkar-pansare |title=Sanatan Sanstha vs SIMI: What Is the Litmus Test for a Ban? |publisher=The Quint |date=2016-06-21 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://twocircles.net/2016jun12/1465750324.html#.V4szsvl97rc |title=Pressure mounts on BJP to ban Sanatan Sanstha after arrest in Dabholkar murder case |publisher=TwoCircles.net |date=2016-06-12 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> * Sanatan Sanstha was included in a list of terrorist organisations by the government of Maharashtra.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.hindujagruti.org/news/10265.html |title=Sanatan Sanstha listed as terrorist organization by Maharashtra Govt. - Hindu Janajagruti Samiti |publisher=Hindujagruti.org |date=2010-09-17 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref> * Residents of Goa have been agitating for a ban on the organisation since 2009.<ref name=villagersdemandbanET>{{cite web|author=|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/goa-ramnathi-villagers-seek-ban-on-sanatan-sanstha/articleshow/49181166.cms |title=Goa: Ramnathi villagers seek ban on Sanatan Sanstha - The Economic Times |website=Economictimes.indiatimes.com |date=2015-10-01 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/goa-village-where-sanatan-sanstha-is-headquartered-want-a-ban-on-it.-give-cm-a-week/1/487802.html |title=Goa village where Sanatan Sanstha is headquartered wants it banned, gives CM a week : India, News - India Today |website=Indiatoday.intoday.in |date=2015-10-01 |accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
===Against a ban===
====BJP==== * On 2 December 2015, Minister of state for home Kiren Rijiju informed that there is no current proposal for imposing a ban on Sanatan Sanstha.<ref name="IND-GOV"/> Dabholkar's family is claiming the link between the three murders and requesting court to club the cases.<ref name="ndtv.com"/><ref name="newsclick.in"/> However, CBI have informed High Court that it is waiting for the ballistic report from Scotland Yard to link all three cases.<ref name="CBI"/> * On 22 September 2015, Former Home Secretary RK Singh told that Home Ministry under the previous UPA government concluded that there was no specific evidence against Sanatan Sanstha, so on that basis they couldn't ban the organization<ref name="ibnlive.com"/>
====Congress==== * In 2011, [[P. Chidambaram]], the Home minister then, had turned down the demand to ban Sanatan Sanstha under section 35(3)(c) of [[UAPA]] citing lack of supporting evidences.<ref name="TheHinduSays" />
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}

page.title: The Book of the Sage and Disciple

revision.text:
{{Ismailis}} '''''The Book of the Sage and Disciple''''' (Arabic: كتاب العالم والغلام ; ''Kitāb al-‘ālim wa-l-ghulām'') is a religious narrative of [[Initiation|spiritual initiation]] written in the form of a [[Dialogue in writing|dramatic dialogue]] by Ja‘far bin Manṣūr al-Yaman (270 AH/883 CE – c. 347 AH/958 CE). The work describes the encounter of a disillusioned young man with a [[Dawah|''dā‘ī'']], or [[Isma'ilism|Ismāʿīlī]] Muslim missionary, who gradually introduces his new disciple to the inner dimensions of Islam as elaborated by the Shī‘ī [[Imamah (Shia doctrine)|imāms]].
Ismāʿīlī Muslims, known less commonly as ''Seveners'', are Shī‘ī Muslims who believe that [[Isma'il ibn Jafar|Ismāʿīl ibn Ja‘far]] (b. 100/719) was the true prophetic successor or imām of [[Ja'far al-Sadiq|Ja‘far al-Sādiq]] (d. 148/765), as opposed to [[Twelver|Ithnā‘asharī]] or ''Twelvers'' who believe that [[Musa al-Kadhim|Mūsā al-Kāẓim]] (d. 183/799) was designated imām over his younger brother Ismāʿīl. After the [[Abbasid Caliphate|‘Abbāsid Revolution]] of 750 CE Ismāʿīlīs came to believe that [[Muhammad ibn Ismail|Muḥammad ibn Ismāʿīl]], son of the seventh imām and their awaited [[madhi]], had entered a [[The Occultation|state of occultation]]. In his absence Ismāʿīlīs began widely propagating their faith beyond their base of power in [[the Levant]] through the institution of the ''da‘wa'', or mission led by a dā‘ī.<ref>{{cite book|last=Daftary|first=Farhad|title=A Short History of the Ismailis|year=1998|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|location=Edinburgh|pages=36–50}}</ref> In addition to presiding over the primary missionary activities of the da‘wa, the dā‘ī was responsible for the education, safety and spiritual health of his community. The personal relationship of the dā‘ī and his students, portrayed so vividly by Ja‘far bin Manṣūr al-Yaman in his ''Kitāb'', would decisively influence the [[Tariqa|sheikh-murīd bond]] of later [[Sufi]] orders. With the rise of the [[Fatimid Caliphate|Fāṭimid dynasty]] in the first quarter of the tenth century CE, Ismāʿīlīs identified these caliphs with their imāms.<ref>{{cite book|last=Daftary|first=Farhad|title=The Ismāʿīlīs: Their History and Doctrines|year=1990|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, England|pages=104}}</ref>
In this manner the ''Kitāb'' is to be viewed as a classic of early Fāṭimid literature, documenting important aspects of the development of the Ismāʿīlī da‘wa in tenth-century [[Yemen]]. The ''Kitāb'' is also of considerable historical value for modern scholars of Arabic prose literature as well as those interested in the relationship of esoteric Shī‘ism with early Islamic mysticism. Likewise is the ''Kitāb'' an important source of information regarding the various movements within tenth-century Shī‘ism leading to the spread of the Fāṭimid-Isma‘īlī da‘wa throughout the medieval Islamicate world, and the religious and philosophical history of post-Fāṭimid [[Mustaali|Musta‘lī]] branch of Ismāʿīlism in Yemen and [[India]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Morris|first=J.W.|title=The Master and the Disciple: an Early Islamic Spiritual Dialogue|year=2001|publisher=IB Taurus|location=London|pages=6–17}}</ref>
== The Author ==
Ja‘far bin Manṣūr al-Yaman was a high-ranking Ismāʿīlī poet, theologian and court companion active during the reign of the first four Fāṭimid caliphs. Born to an accomplished Shī‘ī family of [[Kufa]]n origins in Yemen, Ja‘far was a son of the famous Ismāʿīlī proselytizer ibn Hawshāb (d. 302AH/914CE). As a result of his pioneering work establishing the Isma‘lī da‘wa of Yemen, ibn Hawshāb was commonly known by the [[laqab]] Manṣūr al-Yaman (“the Conqueror of Yemen”), whence derives Ja‘far's [[Patronymic#Arabic|patronymic]]. As the only son of ibn Hawshāb to follow in his footsteps after his death, Ja‘far was often at odds with his brother Abū al-Ḥasan. Their mutual estrangement eventually forced Ja‘far to emigrate to [[Maghreb|North Africa]], where he arrived during the reign of the second Faṭimid caliph [[Al-Qa'im Bi-Amrillah|al-Qā'im]] (r. 322-34AH/933-46CE).<ref>{{cite book|last=Ḥammādi|first=Moḥammad b. Mālek|title=Kašf asrār al-bāṭeniya wa aḵbār al-Qarāmeṭa|year=1939|location=Cairo}}</ref> There he witnessed the anti-Fāṭimid revolt led by [[Khawarij|Khārajī]] [[Berber people|Berber]] [[Abu Yazid|Abū Yazīd]], which began in the last two years of al-Qā'im's reign and ended in the first regnal year of his successor, [[Al-Mansur Billah|al-Manṣūr]] (r. 334-41AH/946-53CE).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Haji|first=Hamid|title=Jaʿfar b. Manṣur-al-Yaman|journal=Encyclopaedia Iranica|year=2008|volume=No. XIV|pages=349}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Morris|first=J.W.|title=Reason and Inspiration in Islam|year=2005|publisher=IB Taurus|location=London|pages=102–16}}</ref>
Composed largely during the years 333-36AH/945-48CE, Ja‘far's poetry expressed intense loyalty toward Fāṭimid rule. Many of his compositions also contained [[Esoteric interpretation of the Quran|allegorical interpretations or ta'wīl]] for Qurʾānic words and expressions (''Sarā'ir al-nuṭaqā'' and ''Asrār al-nuṭaqā'') as well as [[Ibadah|Islamic ritual worship]], letters of the [[Arabic alphabet]] (''Risālat ta'wīl ḥurūf al-muʿjam'') and the hierarchy of the Fāṭimid daʿwa (''Kitāb al-kashf,'' ''al-Shawāhid wa-l-bayān'' and ''Kitāb al-farā'iḍ wa ḥudūd al-dīn'').<ref>{{cite book|last=Poonawala|first=Ismail K.|title=Biobibliography of Ismāʿīlī Literature|year=1977|location=Malibu}}</ref>
His early work also celebrated al-Manṣūr's triumph over Abū Yazīd, currying him favor with the caliph. Indeed, Ja‘far maintained a grand residence in [[Mansouria, Tunisia|Manṣūriyya]], a town founded by the eponymous ruler near [[Kairouan|al-Qayrawān]] in honor of this victory. However, later in life Ja‘far found himself in such dire financial straits that he was obliged to mortgage his household at great risk. He was in danger of total forfeiture until the fourth Fāṭimid caliph [[Al-Mu'izz li-Din Allah|al-Mu‘izz]] (r. 341-65/953-75) forgave his debt in recognition of services rendered by Ja‘far and his father ibn Hawshāb. Ja‘far died five years into al-Mu‘izz's reign.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Haji|first=Hamid|title=Jaʿfar b. Manṣur-al-Yaman|journal=Encyclopaedia Iranica|year=2008|volume=No. XIV|pages=349}}</ref>
== The Work ==
''The Book of the Sage and the Disciple'' is one of several pieces of writing attributed to Ja'far that have survived for centuries in Yemen and [[Gujarat]], serving as an important touchestones for spiritual teaching in these communities. Written as a dramatic dialogue, the ''Kitāb'' is noteworthy evidence for the development of this literary form in the Islamicate world in a manner independent from its [[Dialogue#Antiquity and the middle ages|Greek iterations]]. The work also describes the development of Shī'ī religious life in the early medieval period through the proliferation of tariqa Shi'ism and the ethical and spiritual pedagogy of its hierarchical, genealogical structure of filiation and pedigree. These themes are each powerfully in evidence in Ja‘far's ''Kitāb'', and demonstrate the manner in which distinctly Shī'ī religious life was later translated into a more widespread mystical sensibility.
The dialogue itself opens with words of gratitude toward the Sage ('''ālim''), who has called the community of the speaker to the true faith, has directed this community toward knowledge and instructed them in correct religious practice. The speaker asks for further clarification on these matters, and the Sage responds by enjoining obedience to his teachings as a means of thanking him, citing correct practice and leading to the path as the best forms of gratitude.
He then offers a parable for his audience about a young man whose journey toward truth takes him from material comfort to spiritual angst, finally culminating in God's illuminating for him the true path—a path which obliges the man to call others to follow him on it. This obligation has been codified in a spiritual hierarchy in which each successive link in the chain of precedence is duty-bound to bring others into the fold. Thus is the man in the parable obliged to wander through many countries as a teacher, until he comes upon a foreign community which is divided on questions of spirituality, and whose interest in religion, proximity to the true path and shared religious affiliation with Islam necessitate the man's intervention. Here he takes on a didactic role, answering questions that the individuals of this community pose to him in order to further pique their interest. The most receptive of these becomes his pupil, and he trains this acolyte in the divine argument (''ḥujja'') concerning the Shī'ī imams and saints ([[Wali|''awliyā''']]).
The Sage then commands his disciple to adhere to the outer meaning of the Qur'an ([[Zahir (Islam)|''ẓāhir'']]). Indeed, all revealed books are complementary in their divine origin, acting in a successive chain of authority mirroring the spiritual hierarchy of the sheikh-murid relationship. The Sage asks five things of his pupil: to adhere to his commands; to conceal nothing from him; to expect selectivity from the Sage in answering his questions; to wait for the Sage to broach new topics; and to hide any concerns he might have from his father. Indeed, the character of the disciple's father seems to stand in for a potentially hostile community from which Shī'ī Muslims are obligated to conceal their true beliefs for fear of violent reprisal (''[[taqiyya]]'').
After a period of study spent under these strictures, the disciple earns regular contact with the sheikh and delivers his oath ([[Bay'ah|''bay'a'']]) to him. After this point the Sage reveals to him the inner beliefs of the Ismāʿīlī Shī'īs ([[Batin (Islam)|''bāṭin'']]), including the esoteric interpretation of [[Cosmology in medieval Islam|Qur'anic cosmology]], which is structured along the intermediaries of [[Prophets in Islam|prophets]], imāms and saints linking human and divine.<ref>{{cite book|last=Morris|first=J.W.|title=Reason and Inspiration in Islam|year=2005|publisher=IB Taurus|location=London|pages=102–16}}</ref>

Cambridge, England: Cambridge University Press. *Haji, Hamid (2008). “Jaʿfar b. Manṣur-al-Yaman” in ''Encyclopaedia Iranica'' Vol. XIV, Fasc. 4. *Ḥammādi, Moḥammad b. Mālek (1939). ''Kašf asrār al-bāṭeniya wa aḵbār al-Qarāmeṭa'', ed. Moḥammad Zāhed b. Ḥasan Kawṯari, Cairo. *Morris, J.W. (2001). ''The Master and the Disciple: an Early Islamic Spiritual Dialogue''. {{italic title}}{{Infobox newspaper|name = The Remnant|type = Biweekly newspaper|founder = Walter Matt|editor = Michael Matt|headquarters = [[Forest Lake, Minnesota]]|website = {{URL|http://www.remnantnewspaper.com}}|ISSN = 0274-9726|owners = The Remnant, Inc.}} '''''The Remnant''''' is a [[Traditionalist Catholic]] newspaper published twice a month in the [[United States]]. Although its editors are not affiliated with any particular institute or traditionalist group, the paper is sympathetic to Archbishop [[Marcel Lefebvre]] and the [[Society of St. Pius X]]. Founded in 1968, it is the oldest Traditionalist Catholic newspaper in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Remnant Newspaper - Our History|url = http://remnantnewspaper.com/web/index.php/our-history|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref> ''The Remnant'' strives to adhere to Catholic teaching in every aspect of its journalism. The name ''The Remnant'' is a reference to the [[Remnant (Bible)|remnant]] of [[Isaiah]] and the belief that only a remnant of Catholics holding to the traditional teachings and practice of the Church remain after the sweeping changes brought by the [[Second Vatican Council]].
==History== ''The Remnant'' traces its roots back to [[The Wanderer (Roman Catholic newspaper)|''The Wanderer'']], the "parent paper" of ''The Remnant'' and the oldest Catholic weekly newspaper in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Remnant Newspaper - Our History|url = http://remnantnewspaper.com/web/index.php/our-history|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref> ''The Remnant'' was a result of a dispute between Walter Matt, the editor of ''The Wanderer'' who served the paper for over thirty years'','' and his brother Alphonse Matt. Walter Matt opposed the changes within the Catholic Church after the Second Vatican Council; Alphonse Matt supported them.
Walter Matt left ''The Wanderer'', which was left under the guidance of Alphonse, to start ''The Remnant'' in 1967, two years before the most dramatic changes, those affecting the Mass and celebration of the Sacraments, were instituted. In Walter Matt's words, his "reaction to what he saw took the form of a Catholic newspaper called ''The Remnant''."<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Remnant Newspaper - Our History|url = http://remnantnewspaper.com/web/index.php/our-history|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref> Thus was founded what was to become the flagship of the traditional Catholic movement in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Remnant Newspaper - Our History|url = http://remnantnewspaper.com/web/index.php/our-history|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref> ''The Remnant'' considers itself as the "leading journal of the counterrevolution, which seeks to restore the traditions of the Church to their rightful place and honor in the Church—especially the [[Tridentine Mass]]." It serves as a forum for Catholics who, in their words, oppose "that which in any way contradicts the [[infallible]] teachings and immutable traditions of the Catholic Church."<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Remnant Newspaper - The Remnant's Statement of Purpose|url = http://remnantnewspaper.com/web/index.php/about-us/item/38-the-remnant-s-statement-of-purpose|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref>
''The Remnant'' is now edited by Walter Matt's youngest son, Michael J. Matt. Many leading traditionalists, including [[Thomas Woods]], [[Brian Mershon]], [[Christopher Ferrara]], Brian McCall, Mark Alessio, Robert Dahl, Kenneth Wolfe, Sherry Foster and Martin Blackshaw write for the paper on a regular basis. Columns by Dr. [[John C. Rao]], a professor at [[St. John's University (New York)|St. John's University]], are another regular feature. So were columns by [[Michael Davies (Catholic writer)|Michael Davies]] for many years before his death in 2004 and by [[Thomas Droleskey]] prior to adopting the [[sedevacantist]] position and taking a job with [[The Four Marks]] monthly located in Ballantine, MT. From 2005 to 2013, ''The Remnant'' was a very vigorous defender of the pontificate of [[Benedict XVI]] as its writers believe he has vindicated them on issues that have divided them from other Traditionalists and from conservative Catholics associated with [[The Wanderer (newspaper)|The Wanderer]], [[EWTN]], and [[Catholic Answers]]. Under the current pontificate of [[Pope Francis]], the newspaper has heavily criticized his policies.
== Additional Projects == * '''Remnant TV''': After producing daily video updates from [[Rome]], Italy during the [[Resignation of Pope Benedict XVI]] and the conclave which ultimately elected [[Pope Francis]], ''The Remnant'' began producing a full range of cutting-edge video commentary and events coverage under the title of Remnant TV. Remnant TV releases weekly [[talk show]] styled [[YouTube]] videos in three series: Remnant TV Forum, Remnant Special Report, and The Remnant Underground. Michael Matt serves as host and principal commentator; regular guests include contributors to the Remnant such as Christopher Ferrara, Brian McCall, John Rao, and other Catholic commentators.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Remnant Newspaper - Remnant Television|url = http://remnantnewspaper.com/web/index.php/remnant-tv|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref> * '''Remnant E-Edition:''' ''The Remnant'' newspaper is also published in electronic format—available to all print subscribers as well as on its own for a reduced rate. The E-Edition is a high fidelity scan of the print edition formatted for reading on one's personal computer, [[Amazon Kindle|Kindle]], [[Barnes & Noble Nook|Nook]], or other e-reader devices. * '''Remnant Tours''': For the past thirty years, ''The Remnant'' has hosted and organized tours and [[pilgrimage]]s to the [[Holy Land]] and throughout Europe. It has also organized the United States Chapter of the three-day [[Chartres Pilgrimage]], a seventy-mile walking pilgrimage from [[Paris]] to [[Chartres Cathedral|Chartres]] during [[Pentecost]] weekend, for the past twenty two years.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Remnant: It's Not Just a Newspaper Anymore!|url = http://remnantnewspaper.com/web/images/pdf/Remnant-Ad.pdf|website = remnantnewspaper.com|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref> * '''Remnant Press''': Having published the works of many Traditionalist Catholics, including [[Dietrich von Hildebrand]], Michael Davies, and Walter Matt, the Remnant Press continues to publish the works of authors in the traditionalist movement. Most recently, the Remnant Press published a collection of Dr. John Senior's essays and a new book on [[Homeschooling]] by Sherry Foster.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Remnant: It's Not Just a Newspaper Anymore!|url = http://remnantnewspaper.com/web/images/pdf/Remnant-Ad.pdf|website = remnantnewspaper.com|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref>
==SPLC criticism== The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] includes ''The Remnant'' and the Remnant Press in its list of "active U.S. hate groups" under the "Radical Traditionalist Catholic" category, which the SPLC defines as "organizations that embrace anti-Semitism and whose theology is typically rejected by the Vatican and mainstream Catholics in general."<ref>[http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/hate-map#s=MN SPLC list of Minnesota-based "hate groups".]</ref> ''The Remnant'' editors reject this label, noting their belief that anti-Semitism is a mortal sin,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Southern Poverty Law Center Accuses Traditionalists of Anti-Semitism|url = http://www.remnantnewspaper.com/Archives/archive-2007-0215-rise_of_militant_christophob.htm|website = www.remnantnewspaper.com|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref> and that the organization is peaceful.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Death to Ratzinger|url = http://www.remnantnewspaper.com/Archives/archive-2007-1015-death-to-ratzinger.htm|website = www.remnantnewspaper.com|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref> Others have also defended ''The Remnant'' from this charge, including the [[Catholic Family News]]<ref>http://www.cfnews.org/SPLC.htm</ref> and Renew America.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Catholic traditionalists fire back at Southern Poverty Law Center|url = http://www.renewamerica.com/columns/abbott/070322|website = www.renewamerica.com|accessdate = 2015-05-25}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.remnantnewspaper.com/ Official site] * [https://www.youtube.com/user/TheRemnantvideo Remnant TV] * [http://focusfeatures.com/pope-francis-a-man-of-his-word| Pope Francis - A Man of His Word - official website]

{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} '''''The Talmud Unmasked''''' (Latin: ''Christianus in Talmud Iudaeorum: sive, Rabbinicae doctrinae Christiani secreta'') is a book published in 1892 by [[Justinas Pranaitis|Justinas Bonaventure Pranaitis]] (1861–1917). The book, generally regarded as [[antisemitic]],<ref name="Levy">{{cite book|last1=Levy|first1=Richard|authorlink1=Richard S. Levy|title=Antisemitism: A Historical Encyclopedia of Prejudice and Persecution, Volume 1|date=2005|publisher=ABC-CLIO Ltd|isbn=978-1851094394|page=564|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tdn6FFZklkcC&pg=PA564&dq=%22The+Talmud+Unmasked%22+antisemitic+Rohling&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPosH356DPAhXEVxoKHYsnBHkQ6AEIJDAB#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Talmud%20Unmasked%22%20antisemitic%20Rohling&f=false|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Harris|first1=Constance|title=The Way Jews Lived: Five Hundred Years of Printed Words and Images|date=2009|publisher=McFarland & Co|isbn=978-0786434404|page=255|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f7ZXXhkkq7EC&pg=PA255&dq=%22The+Talmud+Unmasked%22+antisemitic+Rohling&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPosH356DPAhXEVxoKHYsnBHkQ6AEIKjAC#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Talmud%20Unmasked%22%20antisemitic%20Rohling&f=false|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Fiordo|authorlink1=Richard|editor1-last=van Eemeren|editor1-first=Frans H.|editor1-link=Frans H. van Eemeren|title=Argumentation: Analysis and Practices : Proceedings (Studies of Argumentation in Pragmatics and Discourse Analysis, Vol 3b)|date=1987|publisher=Foris Pubns USA|isbn=978-9067653206|page=299|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dl7HTk02OjYC&pg=PA279&dq=%22The+Talmud+Unmasked%22+antisemitic&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiD2Y_O5qDPAhWKDxoKHenVAxgQ6AEILzAD#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Talmud%20Unmasked%22%20antisemitic&f=false|accessdate=21 September 2016|chapter=The Kcegstra Case: The Anti-Semitic Argument in Modern Day Alberta Schools}}</ref> is a collection of purported quotes from the [[Talmud]] and [[Zohar]] that purports to demonstrate that Judaism despises non-Jews and promotes the murder of non-Jews. Pranaitis drew on the earlier works of Jakob Ecker and [[August Rohling]].<ref name="Levy"/>
==Presentation of the book==
''The Talmud Unmasked'' is a collection of alleged quotes from the [[Talmud]], the Zohar and other Talmudic works purporting to demonstrate that: #Jews do not regard non-Jews as human beings #the Talmud contains blasphemies against Jesus and offensive passages about Christians #Judaism despises non-Jews #the Talmud urges Jews to do a variety of harms to Christians, such as murder and theft, and teaches that each death of a Christian serves as a substitute for the Temple sacrifices, which would then hasten the arrival of the Jewish messiah.<ref name="Levy"/> :"By means of numerous citations in Hebrew and Latin translations, he sought to demonstrate that the Talmud obliged Jews to injure Christians in multifarious ways, and to work for their elimination. Pranaitis drew on the works of the German anti-Talmudists Jakob Ecker and August Rohlong. The book received the imprimatur of the church and was published by the press of the Academy of Sciences." *Michael, Robert, ''Dictionary of antisemitism from the earliest times to the present'', Scarecrow Press, 2007, p 369: :"According to Pranaitis, the Talmud urged Jews to murder Christians, as each death of a Christian serving as a substitute for the Temple sacrifices, would hasten the arrival of the Jewish messiah. The Talmudic and Torah prohibitions about consuming blood were circumvented, according to Pranaitis, by boiling the blood."
===Structure and themes=== A portion of the book's outline is as follows:<ref>Taken from Pranaitis, Justinis, ''The Talmud Unmasked: The Secret Rabbinical Teachings Concerning Christians'', from the English translation [https://books.google.com/books?id=GZZ6EamCbxcC online]</ref> :Chapter I. Christians are to be Avoided ::Art. 1. Christians Unworthy to Associate with Jews ::Art. 2. Christians are Unclean ::Art. 3. Christians are Idolaters ::Art. 4. Christians are Evil :Chapter II. Christians are to be Exterminated ::Art. 1. Christians to be Harmed Indirectly :::1. By not helping them :::2. By interfering in their work :::3. By deceit in legal matters :::4. By harming them in things necessary for life ::Art. 2. Christians to be Harmed Directly :::1. Renegades to be killed :::2. Apostates :::3. Princes especially the Prince of Rome (the Pope) to be exterminated :::4. All Christians to be killed :::5. Killing a Christian is an acceptable sacrifice to God :::6. Heaven promised to those who kill Christians :::7. A Christian may be beheaded on the most solemn festivals :::8. The Messiah expected will be revengeful :::9. Jewish prayers against Christians :::10. Christian prayers for the Jews
===Accuracy and fabrication=== Pranaitis could not read Aramaic (the primary language of the Talmud),<ref>{{cite book|last1=Afran|first1=Bruce|last2=Garber|first2=Robert|title=Jews On Trial|year=2004|publisher=KTAV|isbn=9780881258684|pages=87–88}}</ref> and probably used works by August Rohling and others as his sources.
The book includes numerous quotes from the [[Talmud]] and the [[Zohar]].<ref name="Kaplan"/> His ignorance of some simple Talmudic Aramaic concepts and definitions, such as "hullin", was demonstrated during the [[Menahem Mendel Beilis]] [[blood libel]] case in which he testified as a "Talmud expert".<ref>Blood Accusation: The Strange History of the Beiliss Case, Samuel, Maurice, Alfred A. Knopf, 1966.</ref><ref>Scapegoat on Trial: The Story of Mendel Beilis – The Autobiography of Mendel Beilis the Defendant in the Notorious 1912 Blood Libel in Kiev, Beilis, Mendel, Introd. & Ed. By Shari Schwartz, CIS, New York, 1992, {{ISBN|1-56062-166-4}}</ref>
==Antisemitism== Scholars classify ''The Talmud Unmasked'' as an antisemitic and anti-Talmudic work, comparable to ''Der Talmud Jude'' by [[August Rohling]] (1871) and ''The Traditions Of The Jews'' by [[Johann Eisenmenger]] (1700).
==Use by apocalyptic cults== [[Jeffrey Kaplan (academic)|Jeffrey Kaplan]] describes how the book was used by cults to support apocalyptic theories, particular relating to the [[eschatology|end-of-times]].<ref name="Kaplan">Kaplan, Jeffrey, ''Radical religion in America: millenarian movements from the far right to the children of Noah'', Syracuse University Press, 1997, pp 119–120: :Kaplan quotes Pranaitis, p 83: "VII. Those who Kill Christians Shall Have a High Place in Heaven In Zohar (I, 38b, and 39a) it says: 'In the places of the fourth heaven are those who lamented over Sion and Jerusalem, and all those who destroyed idolatrous nations ... and those who killed off people who worship idols are clothed in purple garments so that they may be recognised and honored" ... VIII. Jews must never cease to Exterminate the Goim; they must never leave them in peace and never submit to them.... In Hilkoth Akum (X, 1) it says: 'Do not eat with idolaters, nor permit them to worship their idols; for it is written: Make not covenant with them, nor show mercy unto them (Deut. ch 7), … Either turn them away from their idols or kill them' .... In Zhohar (I,25) it says: 'The People of the Earth are idolaters, and it has been written about them: Let them be wiped off the face of the earth. Destroy the memory of the Amalekites. They are with us still in the Fourth Captivity, namely, the Princes [of Rome] . . . who are really Amalekites." </ref>

Li Yujie (1978) | founded_date = 20th century | founded_place = [[Anhui]], [[Taiwan]] | members = 2005, combined membership in Taiwan: 500.000 (2.2%) }} {{Chinese folk religion}} '''Tiandiism'''{{efn|Religion of the "Heavenly Deity" or "Universal Lord" (''Tiāndì'' {{lang|zh|天帝}})}} is a group of [[Chinese folk religious sects]], namely the Holy Church of the Heavenly Virtue{{efn|天德圣教 ''Tiāndé shèngjiào''}} and the Lord of Universe Church,{{efn|天帝教 ''Tiāndì jiāo''}} which emerged respectively from the teachings of Xiao Changming and Li Yujie, disseminated in the early 20th century.Vermander, 1999. The Lord of Universe Church is actually a later development of the former, established in the 1980s. These religions focus on the worship of the "Heavely Deity" or "Heavenly Emperor" (''Tiāndì'' 天帝), on health through the proper cultivation of [[qi]], and teach a style of [[qigong]] named ''Tianren qigong''.Micollier, 1998. According to scholars, the doctrines of Li Yujie are traceable to the [[Taoism|Taoist]] tradition of [[Mount Hua|Huashan]],Ju Keyi, Lu Xianlong. 2014. p. 195 where he studied for eight years.Palmer, 2011. p. 27 The Lord of Universe Church is active both in Taiwan and mainland China, where it has high-level links. ==Tiandiist bodies== ===Holy Church of the Heavenly Virtue=== The origins of the Holy Church of the Heavenly Virtue (天德圣教 ''Tiāndé shèngjiào'') go back to [[Sichuan]] in 1899, with the alleged resurrection of a young boy named Xiao Changming (蕭昌明, 1896-1943) who had apparently died three days earlier. After his revival, he declared that he had received Heaven's mandate (''tianming'') to save humanity from suffering. He embarked on a successful religious career and attracted a large following. In 1937 he established his headquarters on Mount Huang in southern [[Anhui]] province where he died in 1943. Like other sects, Xiao Changming's movement was suppressed in [[China]] after 1949, but survives in [[Taiwan]] and [[Hong Kong]]. In Taiwan, one of Xiao's disciples, Li Yujie, eventually decided to walk his own path and founded a new group called the Lord of Universe Church in 1978, which diverges doctrinally in several aspects from the mother group, yet also sees itself in the tradition of Xiao Changming's teachings. Currently, there exist two regional organizations for this religion. Its [[Hong Kong]] headquarters is located at Castle Peak in the New Territories. In [[Taiwan]] the religion's situation is characterized by disunity, with several separate organizations claiming to continue original Xiao's teachings. ===Lord of Universe Church=== [[File:Tian'an Taihe Temple, Lord of Universe Church-2.JPG|thumb|150px|Tiandi church under construction in [[Miaoli County]], [[Taiwan]].]] The Lord of Universe Church (天帝教 ''Tiāndì jiāo'') is based in [[Taiwan]] and is devoted to the Tiandist beliefs as proclaimed by Li Yujie. It is an offshoot of the Holy Church of the Heavenly Virtue and it emphasizes chanting, traditional medicine, and a form of meditation which it calls "quiet sitting" in English. Li Yujie was born in [[China]]. He worked in the [[Guomindang]] but left in 1958 to ensure political independence for his fledgling newspaper. In 1980 he claimed he was given permission by God to retransmit the message of the Heavenly Deity, which emphasize [[nuclear disarmament]] and [[Chinese unification]]. His book, ''The Ultimate Realm'', was translated into Japanese and English under his guidance. ==See also== * [[Tian]] * [[Xiantiandao]] * [[Chinese folk religion]] * [[Taoism]] * [[Confucianism]] ==Bibliography== * {{cite web | title = An introduction to the Lord of Universe Church | publisher = [[eRenlai]] | url = http://www.erenlai.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3975%3Atiantijiao-introduction&catid=688%3Aoctober-2010&Itemid=331&lang=en | accessdate= 2010-10-06}} * D. The '''Universal Call to Holiness''' is a teaching of the [[Roman Catholic Church]] that all people are called to be [[sacred|holy]], and is based on Matthew 5:48 – "Be you therefore perfect, as also your heavenly Father is perfect."[https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew+5%3A48&version=DRA Matthew 5:48]. In the opening pages of the Bible, the call to holiness is expressed in the Lord's words to Abraham: “Walk before me, and be blameless” (Gen 17:1).{{cite book |last1=[[Pope Francis]] |title=[[Gaudete et exsultate|Gaudete Et Exsultate]]: On the call to holiness in today's world |date=2018 |publisher=Libreria Editrice Vaticana |ref=Gaudete}} ==History== The universal call to holiness has always been a teaching of the Church and is rooted in its mission to take sinners and raise them from their sinful nature into saints by the glory and perfection of Jesus Christ. For God does not choose us by our virtue or goodness, but by His infinite mercy and desire for all men's salvation. An example of this teaching can be found in the ''[[Introduction to the Devout Life]]'' of [[Francis de Sales]]. Written in the 17th century, it describes a method to approach holiness in everyday life.[http://pathoflifeblog.blogspot.com/2011/12/universal-call-to-holiness.html Wagner, Francis de Sales O.S.B., "The universal call to holiness", St. Meinrad Archabbey, December 14, 2011] ==Description== Chapter V of the Dogmatic Constitution on the Church, ''[[Lumen gentium]]'' discusses the Universal Call to Holiness:
...all the faithful of Christ of whatever rank or status, are called to the fullness of the Christian life and to the perfection of charity; ...They must follow in His footsteps and conform themselves to His image seeking the will of the Father in all things. They must devote themselves with all their being to the glory of God and the service of their neighbor.[http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19641121_lumen-gentium_en.html Pope Paul VI, ''Lumen gentium'', §40, November 21, 1964] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906031754/http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19641121_lumen-gentium_en.html |date=September 6, 2014 }}
Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI spoke on the Universal Call to Holiness during his General Audience of Wednesday, 13 April 2011, saying:
"...The saints expressed in various ways the powerful and transforming presence of the Risen One. They let Jesus so totally overwhelm their life that they could say with St Paul “it is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me” (Gal 2:20). Following their example, seeking their intercession, entering into communion with them, “brings us closer to Christ, so our companionship with the saints joins us to Christ, from whom as from their fountain and head issue every grace and the life of the People of God itself” (cf. Second Vatican Council, Dogmatic Constitution on the Church, Lumen Gentium, n. 50). At the end of this series of Catecheses, therefore, I would like to offer some thoughts on what holiness is. What does it mean to be holy? Who is called to be holy? We are often led to think that holiness is a goal reserved for a few elect. St Paul, instead, speaks of God’s great plan and says: “even as he (God) chose us in him [Christ] before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless before him” (Eph 1:4). And he was speaking about all of us. At the centre of the divine plan is Christ in whom. God shows his Face, in accord with the favour of his will. The Mystery hidden in the centuries is revealed in its fullness in the Word made flesh. And Paul then says: “in him all the fullness of God was pleased to dwell” (Col 1:19)... The Second Vatican Council, in the Dogmatic Constitution on the Church, speaks with clarity of the universal call to holiness, saying that no one is excluded: “The forms and tasks of life are many but holiness is one — that sanctity which is cultivated by all who act under God’s Spirit and… follow Christ, poor, humble and cross-bearing, that they may deserve to be partakers of his glory” (Lumen Gentium, n. 41)" [http://w2.vatican.va/content/benedict-xvi/en/audiences/2011/documents/hf_ben-xvi_aud_20110413.html]
The universal call to holiness is rooted in [[baptism]], and the [[Paschal Mystery]], which configures a person to Jesus Christ who is truly God and truly man, thus uniting a person with the Second Person of the [[Trinity|Blessed Trinity]], bringing him in communion with intra-trinitarian life.
Since 1928, [[St. Josemaría Escrivá]], the founder of Opus Dei, also preached the universal call to holiness especially for lay people living an everyday life and doing ordinary work: "There is something holy, something divine, hidden in the most ordinary situations, and it is up to each of you to discover it."{{cite book|last1=Escriva|first1=Josemaria|title=Conversations With Josemaria Escriva|date=1993|publisher=Scepter|location=New York}} [[Pope John Paul II|John Paul II]] states in his apostolic Letter ''[[Novo Millennio Ineunte]]'',[http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/apost_letters/documents/hf_jp-ii_apl_20010106_novo-millennio-ineunte_en.html Novo Millenio Ineunte] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419003703/http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/apost_letters/documents/hf_jp-ii_apl_20010106_novo-millennio-ineunte_en.html |date=April 19, 2012 }} his [[apostolic letter]] for the new millennium, a "program for all times", that holiness is not only a state but a task, whereby Christians should strive for a full Christian life, imitating Christ, God the Son, who gave his life for God the Father and for his neighbor. This entails a "training in the art of [[prayer]]". According to the Pope, all [[Pastoral care#Roman Catholicism|pastoral initiatives]] have to be set in relation to holiness, as this has to be the topmost priority of the Church. The universal call to holiness is explained as more fundamental than the [[Vocational discernment in the Catholic Church|vocational discernment]] to particular ways of life such as [[priesthood]], [[marriage]], or [[virginity]]. At the very core of the [[Catholic spirituality|spirituality of a Catholic]] is this call to perfection. ==See also== {{Portal|Saints|Bible|Catholicism|Christianity}} *[[Apostolates]] *[[Opus Dei]] *[[Christian perfection]] *[[Prayer, meditation and contemplation in Christianity]] *[[Vocational discernment in the Catholic Church]] *[[Familiaris consortio]] *[[Amoris laetitia]] ==References== {{Lay Cath Spirituality|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Universal Call To Holiness}} [[Category:Catholic doctrines]] [[Category:Holiness]]

{{EngvarB|date=May 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Vaishnavism}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2013}} '''Visvanatha Chakravarti Thakura''' (c. 1626 – c. 1708) was a [[Gaudiya Vaishnavism|Gaudiya Vaishnava]] [[acharya]] born in the village of Devagram within [[Nadia district]], [[West Bengal]], [[India]]. His parents were Radhi Sreni brahmanas. He also had two brothers named Rambhadra and Raghunatha.
His initiating guru was Sriyuta Krsnacarana Cakravarti of Saiyadabad, Murshidabad, who was fourth in the line from [[Narottama Dasa]]. Visvanatha Chakravarti resided with his guru for many years and composed many books during that time.
His studies of grammar, poetry and rhetoric were completed while he still lived at Nadia. There is a story that he defeated one conquering pandit while he himself was still only a student. From his childhood he was completely indifferent to household life. In order to keep him at home, his father had him married at a very young age. However, he finally renounced family life and came to live at [[Vrindavana]]. His family members tried to bring him back but were unsuccessful.
Sri Chakravarti Thakura took up residence with Mukunda Dasa, who lived in [[Krishnadasa Kaviraja]] Gosvami's bhajana kutir at [[Radha-kunda]]. There he very intently studied the books and letters of the Gosvamis and composed many commentaries on their writings.
He used to worship a Deity named Golokananda. His another name was Harivallabha Dasa.
He composed the following books on [[Gaudiya Vaishnava Theology]]:<ref>{{cite book|author=Śrī Śrīmad Bhaktivedānta Nārāyaṇa Gosvāmī Mahārāja|title=Bhagavad-Gita|publisher=Gaudiya Vedanta Publications|year=2011|edition=Third|isbn=9781935428398}}</ref>
*Vraja-riti-cintamani *Camatkara-candrika *Prema-samputa *Gitavali *Subodhini, a commentary on the Alankara-Kaustabha *Ananda-Candrika, a commentary on Ujjvala-Nilamani *A commentary on the [[Gopala Tapani Upanishad]] *Stavamrta-Lahri *Sri-Krishna-bhavanamrta-mahakavya *Sri Bhagavatamrta Kana *Sri Ujjavala-nilamani-kirana *Sri Bhakti-rasamrta-sindhu-bindu *Dana-Keli Kaumudi-tika *Sri Lalita-madhava-nataka-tika *Sri Caitanya-caritamrta-tika(incomplete) *Brahma-Samhita-tika *Sarartha-Varsini tika *Sarartha-darsini tika
He died on the [[Vasanta-pancami]] in the month of [[Magha (month)|Magha]].
